palmier good evening I'm Victor
palmier tonight The Advocates begins its
third season of weekly broadcast and
it's my pleasure to welcome back those
of you who were among our regular
viewers last year to welcome those who
are with us for the first time tonight
The Advocates have been introduced but
let me tell you a little more about them
Howard Miller who returns with us for
the third year also returns this year to
the University of Southern California
where he is a professor of Law and
William rusher who joined us last year
is a lawyer former special counsel for
the Senate internal security
subcommittee and the publisher of the
widely respected conservative Journal
National Review
in future broadcast we'll be drawing
upon a pool of distinguished men and
women in public life who will join us as
guest advocates in an attempt to bring
Illuminating debate to the important
public issues of our
day now to tonight's question should the
government drop charges against Daniel
Ellsberg Advocate Howard Miller says
yes the government is about to prosecute
Daniel ellberg for returning a set of
documents to those who own them the
people of the United
States those Prosecuting are the very
people who support the policy that
ellsburg exposed as a fraud in a kind of
premature
1984 the LIE is Prosecuting the
truth with me tonight to urge that the
government reassert its integrity and
drop the charges against Daniel ellsburg
the former senator from the state of
Alaska Senator Ernest
Greening editor of The Nashville
Tennessean Mr John seen thaler and
professor of linguistics at MIT
Professor Nome
Chomsky despite that eloquent statement
Advocate William russer says no a
Federal grand jury has indicted Daniel
Ellsberg for violating the US criminal
code if this happen to you or me we
would have to stand trial but ellsberg's
friends now argue that he should be
exempt from prosecution because he acted
with a political purpose in mind is this
the kind of America we want should there
be one law for Daniel Ellsberg and
another for the rest of us with me
tonight to answer no to these questions
are Mr Leo churn executive director of
the Research Institute of America former
United States Ambassador Elbridge
Deron gentlemen thank you very much and
now for some background on tonight's
question in June of
1967 then Secretary of Defense Robert
mcamera ordered a secret study to be
made of United States involvement in
Indochina since the end of World War II
36 persons drawn from the Department of
State and defense as well as from
several private research organizations
worked on the study it took over 18
months to complete and when finished
amounted to 47 volumes containing many
classified doc doents and a narrative
account highly critical of us
involvement in the Vietnam War in all
over 2 and a half million words in March
1971 the New York Times came into
possession of a copy of the still
classified study 3 months later it
published the first of a series of
articles based on the revelations
contained in the so-called Pentagon
Papers a government effort to block
publication of the papers was finally
denied by the Supreme Court without
touching the question of whether a crime
had been committed by the summer much of
the secret study had appeared in print
the government has accused MIT Professor
Daniel Ellsberg who worked on the study
of having played a key role in releasing
it to the Press specifically it has
accused him of violation of the
Espionage Act which makes unauthorized
possession of classified documents
relating to National Security a crime
and with stealing government
property well the issue of Daniel
ellsberg's guilt innocence is not the
only issue raised by the Pentagon papers
were presidents Kennedy and Johnson
guilty of deliberately misleading the
American public his classification of
documents by government frustrating a
legitimate right to
know but tonight we deal with another
issue the issue of personal
responsibility should the government
drop charges against one Daniel ellberg
that's a question we considered tonight
and now of the cases Mr Miller tell us
why the government should drop those
charges the question is often asked what
if others do what Daniel Ellsberg has
done the answer to that question is
another question what if they
don't if at this moment another Vietnam
were being plann secretly and
deceitfully wouldn't we want another
Daniel Ellsberg to tell us about it
now in fact Daniel ellberg has breached
no law the law under which he was
indicted required that it result in
injury to the United States the
disclosure has resulted in benefit to
the United States what Daniel ellberg
did is commit the unforgivable sin he
breached the wall of secrecy between the
government and the people but many
others have done so in the New York
Times case Benjamin Bradley the editor
of the Washington Post submitted an
affidavit which stated that on Wednesday
June 16th 1971 he visited the offices of
Hol Reinhardt and Winston in New York
City where he was shown Galley proofs of
former President Johnson's book and that
many other editors reporters and
newspaper Syndicate Representatives have
had the same opportunity Bradley goes on
the manuscript contains extensive
verbatim quotations from classified
documents contained in the materials
involved in the ellsburg
case can we permit an ex-president to
sell classified information for profit
and at the same time prosecute an ex
official who releases it for the public
information and good to speak to the
point that Daniel ellberg should not be
prosecuted our first witness is Senator
Ernest
Greening Senator we're very glad to have
you on The
Advocates GL to be here Ernest greeting
has been senator from the state of
Alaska and was one of the two United
States senators to vote against the Gulf
of Tonkin Resolution Senator Greening
should we prosecute Daniel ellur
certainly not not only should he not be
prosecuted but he should be rewarded he
should be honored for the inestimable
valuable service that he has rendered
the people of this country what is the
service that he has rendered well he has
exposed the deception the Betrayal of
the elected public servants of their
responsibility to the American people he
has exposed how the leading officials
starting with the president and all his
surrounding
advisers Li
the American people into this war with
the countless deaths and wounded and all
the other disastrous
consequences he has exposed how the
tonen Gulf resolution was a completely
spurious episode and how the tonen Gulf
resolution had been drafted months
before by an assistant Secretary of
State before the tonen gulf episode
happened he has exposed how while Lyndon
Johnson was campaigning for election in
his own right and telling the American
people people that he would never send
American boys to fight a ground war on
the continent of Asia that he would
never send them to fight do the fighting
that Asian boys should be doing all the
time he was planning to do this and
escalating the war this is an import an
important revelation of inestimable
value to the American people it will
make them Alert in the future to see
that this sort of thing can't happen
what is the effect of the classification
or secrecy system he is supposed to have
violate it merely keeps the American
people in ignorance while it does not
conceal these facts from the enemy has
ellsberg's disclosures caused any harm
or injury to the United States as is
required for him to be prosecuted and
none whatsoever on the contrary they
have done unmitigated good what is then
the good that they have done is what
you've previously well they show the
American people that even their elected
officials can't be trusted that they
have been betrayed by them and that this
betrayal may be going on right today it
has alerted the press to be far more
Vigilant in safeguarding the public
interest than it has been through this
tragic Vietnam Affair if the Press had
performed his full Duty we might not be
in this horrible mess and this is one of
the many services he's rendered and
another service that he's rendered he
has shown up how utterly valous and
wrong this classification system is by
which any pipsqueak official can stamp a
document and call it top secret and keep
this information from the American
people whose Duty it is whose
responsibility is to have this
information so they can exercise their
franchise intelligently the whole issue
of government by consent of the
government is involved and so ellsburg
should have the equivalent of a
Congressional Medal of Honor if there
was such an award to be given to a man
in Civil Life thank you Senator Senator
